context_meta.summary: President Donald Trump fervently advocated for religious liberty in a speech before a group of conservative Christian voters Friday, citing the protection of religious freedom guaranteed by the First Amendment, even as his critics pointed to that same amendment earlier in the week as he suggested blocking freedom of the press. Trump's remarks came at the Values Voter Summit in Washington, D.C. where he became the first sitting president to address the event hosted by the Family Research Council -- a religious non-profit lobbying organization that promotes what it describes as "traditional values". As was the case in his two prior appearances at the summit as a presidential candidate, Trump focused much of his energy on the theme of protecting freedom of religion, and argued he has followed through on his campaign promises..

I have always said their should be a mandatory course patients and visitors have to take while being in a hospital. And don't get me started on the ppl that try to tell me how to do my job. I went to school for this and I'm all for advocating for yourself cause nurses and doctors do make mistakes but do so with respect.

text:
Gayle McLaughlin doesn't know what she's talking about. When I was 18 I made some poor choices and found myself incarcerated. I was given the choice of sitting on my butt for 6 months or going to a fire camp. I chose the fire camp. I was trained by professional fire fighters and had the opportunity to improve myself, physically, mentally and spiritually. I helped fight fires that threatened Pepperdine University and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, as well as saving the homes of many people. The gratitude expressed by the people that nearly lost everything is something I will never forget. I experienced pride and self worth by giving of myself and getting nothing in return.
  Had I simply sat around for 6 months, my experience in jail would have been much different. I can't envision any scenarios that would have given me the opportunity to be a better person leaving jail than I was before I entered.
  I can't speak for anyone other than myself, but my experience change my life forever. That was the first and last time I was incarcerated.

For more than two years, he worked with one of some 200 crews of inmate-firefighters who in summer and fall spend more time battling blazes in the forests of California than sitting behind bars. This week, for instance, 553 inmates were sent to help take on the blazes ravaging the wine country north of San Francisco.
